questions.text: While at the beach in Florida after final exams, a medical student steps on a stingray, which responds by stinging her in the ankle. The stinger pierces the skin, subcutaneous tissue, and flexor retinaculum of the ankle. Which other structure passing under the retinaculum may be injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The tibial nerve passes under the flexor retinaculum along with tendons and vessels in the tarsal tunnel, making it vulnerable in this injury.

  • The flexor retinaculum (laciniate ligament) is a thickened band on the medial side of the ankle, extending from the medial malleolus to the calcaneus.
  • Structures pass deep to it through the tarsal tunnel, arranged anterior to posterior as: ("Tom, Dick, And Nervous Harry")
    • T: Tibialis posterior tendon
    • D: Flexor Digitorum longus tendon
    • A: Posterior tibial Artery
    • N: Tibial Nerve
    • H: Flexor Hallucis longus tendon
  • Injury to the tibial nerve in this area can result in tarsal tunnel syndrome, presenting with sensory loss or burning pain in the sole and weak foot muscles.

Explanation of other options:

Tibialis anterior (Option B): Passes in the anterior compartment of the leg, not beneath the flexor retinaculum.

Quadratus plantae (Option C): Located in the sole of the foot, not near the ankle or tarsal tunnel.

Anterior tibial artery (Option D): Travels in the anterior compartment, becomes the dorsalis pedis artery, not under the flexor retinaculum.

choices.text: It arises from the femoral nerve and supplies the skin of the dorsum of the foot.
It is a branch of the tibial nerve and supplies most of the intrinsic muscles of the sole.
It originates from the deep fibular nerve and innervates the anterior compartment muscles.
It is a continuation of the saphenous nerve and controls dorsiflexion of the foot.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the lateral plantar nerve is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lateral plantar nerve is the branch of the tibial nerve.

  • The lateral plantar nerve is one of the two terminal branches of the tibial nerve, dividing in the tarsal tunnel.
  • It supplies:
    • Muscles: Most intrinsic muscles of the sole (e.g., quadratus plantae, abductor digiti minimi, lateral 3 lumbricals, adductor hallucis, interossei).
    • Skin: Lateral 1.5 digits and associated sole.
  • Injury results in:
    • Weakness in toe abduction/adduction.
    • Clumsiness in toe movements.
    • Loss of sensation in lateral plantar foot.


Explanation of other options:

Femoral nerve (Option A): Supplies anterior thigh muscles, not involved in plantar innervation.

Deep fibular nerve (Option C): Innervates anterior leg compartment and dorsal foot muscles, not the sole.

Saphenous nerve (Option D): Purely sensory; supplies medial leg and foot, no role in motor control or sole innervation.

questions.text: A medical student goes for a swim while on vacation in Florida after final exams. A barracuda bites his foot, severing an artery on the dorsum of his foot just below his ankle. Which artery has been severed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The dorsalis pedis artery lies on the dorsum of the foot just distal to the ankle joint and is the main artery severed in trauma to this region.

  • The dorsalis pedis artery is the continuation of the anterior tibial artery after it crosses the ankle joint.
  • It runs just lateral to the extensor hallucis longus tendon, over the dorsum of the foot, and is palpable in clinical examination.
  • It gives off branches such as the arcuate artery and dorsal metatarsal arteries.
  • Because of its superficial location, it is easily damaged in penetrating trauma, such as animal bites or sharp lacerations, just distal to the ankle.

Explanation of other options:

Lateral plantar artery (Option A): Arises from the posterior tibial artery, runs on the plantar (sole) side, not on the dorsum of the foot.

Medial plantar artery (Option C): Also a plantar branch, supplies medial side of the sole, not present on dorsum.

Posterior tibial artery (Option D): Lies posterior to the medial malleolus, not on the dorsum, and gives rise to plantar arteries, not injured in dorsal foot trauma.

questions.text: While walking barefoot on the beach in Florida following final exams, a medical student steps on a sharp shell which punctures the sole of her foot. She notices that she can no longer spread her toes apart (without using her hands, that is). Which nerve must have been injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lateral plantar nerve innervates the interossei muscles, which are responsible for toe abduction, spreading the toes apart.

  • The lateral plantar nerve, a terminal branch of the tibial nerve, supplies most of the intrinsic muscles of the foot, including the dorsal and plantar interossei, which perform abduction and adduction of the toes.
  • When a sharp object punctures the lateral plantar surface of the foot, this nerve is at risk of injury.
  • Damage to this nerve results in:
    • Loss of function of the interossei, hence inability to spread (abduct) or bring together (adduct) the toes.
    • Possible sensory deficits over the lateral sole and lateral 1.5 toes.
  • The medial plantar nerve, in contrast, innervates more medial muscles (like abductor hallucis and the first lumbrical) and does not control toe spreading.


Explanation of other options:

Deep fibular nerve (Option A): Innervates extensor digitorum brevis and extensor hallucis brevis on the dorsum of the foot and not involved in toe spreading, which is mediated by plantar interossei.

Medial plantar nerve (Option C): Innervates the abductor hallucis, flexor digitorum brevis, flexor hallucis brevis, and first lumbrical that controls toe flexion and big toe abduction, not toe abduction of digits 2-5.

Sural nerve (Option D): Purely sensory, supplying the posterolateral leg and lateral foot; does not innervate any intrinsic muscles of the foot.

questions.text: In an accident involving farm machinery, a farmer receives a cut on the dorsum of his ankle. As you inspect the wound and test for functional and sensory deficits, you find that no tendons have been cut, but the dorsalis pedis artery and the accompanying nerve have been cut. You would expect to find anaesthesia in which of the following regions:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The deep fibular nerve runs with the dorsalis pedis artery and provides sensory innervation to the first interdigital cleft (web space between the great toe and second toe).

  • The dorsalis pedis artery is a continuation of the anterior tibial artery, and it runs on the dorsum of the foot alongside the deep fibular (peroneal) nerve.
  • While this nerve supplies motor innervation to the extensor digitorum brevis and extensor hallucis brevis, it also provides cutaneous sensory innervation to a very specific area:
    • the skin between the first and second toes.
  • Thus, if both the artery and nerve are cut, you would expect:
    • Ischemia of dorsal foot tissues (due to arterial injury),
    • Loss of sensation in the first web space (due to deep fibular nerve injury).

questions.text: Pain may result from friction of the tendon in which of the muscles that passes deep to the anterior fibers of the long plantar ligament.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fibularis longus tendon curves under the foot and passes deep to the long plantar ligament, making it prone to friction and pain in that region.

  • The fibularis longus muscle originates from the upper part of the lateral surface of the fibula and inserts onto the base of the first metatarsal and medial cuneiform.
  • Its tendon travels around the lateral malleolus, then crosses the sole of the foot obliquely, deep to the anterior fibers of the long plantar ligament.
  • Because of this deep passage and mechanical rubbing, inflammation or overuse can lead to friction and pain, particularly in activities that stress the lateral and plantar aspects of the foot (e.g., running, jumping).

Explanation of other options:

Tibialis posterior (Option A): Passes behind the medial malleolus and through the tarsal tunnel, not related to the long plantar ligament.

Flexor hallucis longus (Option B): Runs deep in the posterior compartment, passing through the tarsal tunnel and inserting on the distal phalanx of the big toe, not in contact with long plantar ligament.

Tibialis anterior (Option D): Located anteriorly in the leg, crossing over the dorsum of the foot to insert on medial cuneiform and first metatarsal, nowhere near the long plantar ligament.

questions.text: Compression of the lateral plantar nerve as it passes between the flexor digitorum brevis and quadratus plantae could result in weakness of any of the following actions EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Abduction of the great toe is performed by the abductor hallucis, which is supplied by the medial plantar nerve, and thus not affected by compression of the lateral plantar nerve.

  • The lateral plantar nerve, a terminal branch of the tibial nerve, supplies most of the intrinsic muscles of the foot except the four supplied by the medial plantar nerve.
  • As it passes between flexor digitorum brevis and quadratus plantae, compression of the lateral plantar nerve can lead to weakness of the muscles it innervates,
    • Particularly adductors of the toes (like adductor hallucis), abductor digiti minimi, lumbricals 2-4, and all interossei muscles.
  • Since abductor hallucis is supplied by the medial plantar nerve, its action is preserved even if the lateral plantar nerve is compressed.

Explanation of other options:

Adduction of the middle toe (Option B): Done by plantar interossei, supplied by the lateral plantar nerve, affected in compression.

Abduction of the little toe (Option C): Performed by abductor digiti minimi, supplied by lateral plantar nerve , thus affected.

Adduction of the great toe (Option D): Controlled by adductor hallucis, supplied by lateral plantar nerve, affected in compression.

choices.text: Squeezing the calf with the person lying face down causes the ankle to flex.
The area around the ankle is swollen and painful when touched.
When the person bends the knees while lying face down, the ankle is not flexed.
When the person is standing, there is no gap in the Achilles tendon.

questions.text: Which of the following findings on physical examination is most likely to indicate a tear of the Achilles tendon?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lack of passive plantar flexion when the calf is squeezed or when knees are bent in the prone position indicates a rupture of the Achilles tendon, as the connection between the gastrocnemius-soleus complex and calcaneus is disrupted.

  • The Achilles tendon connects the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles to the calcaneus.
  • A rupture means this connection is lost.
  • Normally, squeezing the calf (Thompson test) or bending the knees while lying prone leads to passive plantarflexion of the foot.
  • If this motion is absent, it strongly indicates a complete tear of the tendon.

Explanation of other options:

Squeezing the calf with the person lying face down causes the ankle to flex (Option A): This is a normal negative Thompson test, meaning the Achilles tendon is intact.

The area around the ankle is swollen and painful when touched (Option B): This is a nonspecific sign; swelling and tenderness can be present in sprains or contusions as well.

When the person is standing, there is no gap in the Achilles tendon (Option D): A palpable gap is often present in Achilles rupture; absence of a gap does not rule out a tear, especially if swelling obscures it.

choices.text: It connects the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles in the calf to an insertion point at the calcaneus
It is the strongest tendon in the body and allows people to push off while walking, running and jumping.
The Achilles tendon is a thick tendon located in the back of the leg.
It receives sensory innervation from the saphenous nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is not correct regarding the marked tendon:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The saphenous nerve does not innervate the Achilles tendon, making Option D incorrect.

  • The Achilles tendon is formed by the confluence of the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles, inserting into the posterior surface of the calcaneus. (Option A ruled out)
  • It is the strongest tendon in the human body and is essential for plantarflexion of the foot, aiding in activities like walking, running, and jumping. (Option B , C ruled out)
  • The tendon itself is avascular, but surrounded by a paratenon that provides blood supply.
  • Sensory innervation is provided via branches of the sural nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is NOT a part of the pes anserinus (goose's foot)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pes anserinus is formed by insertion of Sartorius, Gracilis, and Semitendinosus on the medial tibia, Semimembranosus inserts more posteriorly.

  • The pes anserinus ("goose's foot") is a conjoined tendon of:
    • Sartorius (from anterior compartment of thigh), (Option A ruled out)
    • Gracilis (from medial compartment), and (Option D ruled out)
    • Semitendinosus (from posterior compartment). (Option C ruled out)
  • These three muscles insert together on the anteromedial surface of the proximal tibia.
  • This arrangement provides dynamic stability to the medial knee joint, especially during walking or pivoting movements.

questions.text: Which of the following combinations of muscles correctly represent the components of the triceps surae group?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Only gastrocnemius and soleus form the triceps surae

  • The Triceps surae is the collective name for the two muscles that form the prominent bulk of the posterior calf:
    • Gastrocnemius (with medial and lateral heads)
    • Soleus
  • They converge into the calcaneal (Achilles) tendon to insert into the posterior surface of the calcaneus.
  • These muscles act primarily in plantarflexion of the ankle and are crucial for walking, running, and jumping.

choices.text: A - Flexor digitorum brevis, B - Abductor digiti minimi
A - Abductor hallucis, B - Adductor digiti minimi
A - Abductor digiti minimi, B - Flexor digitorum brevis
A - Adductor digiti minimi, B- Abductor hallucis

questions.text: Identify the marked muscles:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on their location in the first layer of sole muscles, the centrally located muscle is flexor digitorum brevis, and the lateral muscle is abductor digiti minimi.

  • The first layer of the sole of the foot consists of three muscles, from medial to lateral:
    • Abductor hallucis - along the medial border (big toe side)
    • Flexor digitorum brevis - centrally located
    • Abductor digiti minimi - along the lateral side (little toe side)
  • In the image:
    • Muscle A is centrally located, consistent with flexor digitorum brevis, which arises from the calcaneal tuberosity and inserts into the middle phalanges of the lateral four toes.
    • Muscle B is lateral, consistent with abductor digiti minimi, which abducts the little toe.

questions.text: To which layer of the sole does the marked muscle belong?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The muscle marked is Abductor hallucis, which lies medially and is part of the first layer of the sole.

  • The first layer of the sole of the foot includes:
    • Abductor hallucis - medial side (abducts big toe)
    • Flexor digitorum brevis - central muscle (flexes lateral four toes)
    • Abductor digiti minimi - lateral side (abducts little toe)
  • Abductor hallucis, the muscle marked, originates from the medial process of the calcaneal tuberosity and runs along the medial border of the foot to insert on the proximal phalanx of the hallux.

Explanation of other options:

Second layer (Option B): Contains quadratus plantae and lumbricals, not superficial muscles like the marked one.

Third layer (Option C): Contains flexor hallucis brevis, adductor hallucis, and flexor digiti minimi brevis, which lie deeper than the marked muscle.

Fourth layer (Option D): Comprises plantar and dorsal interossei, the deepest group - not applicable here.
